qas.question: Which Gospel says that Mary fulfilled the prophecy of Isaiah?
Until which century was the Virgin birth of Jesus held almost universally among Christians?
What Hebrew word is used to describe Mary in Isaiah 7:14?
Which verse in Luke states that Mary had "no relations with man" before Jesus' birth?
Along with the Nicene Creed, which other Christian creed asserts the Virgin birth of Jesus?
What century was the Apostles' Creed written in?
When Isaiah spoke to Mary he called her by what Hebrew word?
In what century did Mary fulfill the prophecy?
Which creed was written by Isaiah?

context: The Virgin birth of Jesus was an almost universally held belief among Christians from <b7_0>the 2nd<b7_0/> until <b5_0>the <a1_0>19th<a1_0/> century<b5_0/>. It is included in the two most widely used Christian creeds, which state that Jesus "was incarnate of the Holy Spirit and the Virgin Mary" (<b8_0>the Nicene Creed<b8_0/> in what is now its familiar form) and <a4_0>the Apostles' Creed<a4_0/>. The Gospel of <a0_0>Matthew<a0_0/> describes Mary as a virgin who fulfilled the prophecy of Isaiah 7:14, mistranslating the Hebrew word <a2_0><b6_0>alma<b6_0/><a2_0/> ("young woman") in Isaiah 7:14 as "virgin", though.[citation needed] The authors of the Gospels of Matthew and Luke consider Jesus' conception not the result of intercourse and assert that Mary had "no relations with man" before Jesus' birth.[Mt 1:18] [Mt 1:25] [Lk <a3_0>1:34<a3_0/>] This alludes to the belief that Mary conceived Jesus through the action of God the Holy Spirit, and not through intercourse with Joseph or anyone else.
